body: ${1:CREATE MODEL | CREATE MODEL IF NOT EXISTS | CREATE OR REPLACE MODEL} `${2:project}.${3:dataset}.${4:model}`

CAST().description: Cast syntax is used in a query to indicate that the result type of an expression should be converted to some other type.

SAFE_CAST().description: SAFE_CAST is identical to CAST, except it returns NULL instead of raising an error.

ANY_VALUE().description: Returns any value from the input or NULL if there are zero input rows.

ARRAY_CONCAT_AGG().description: Concatenates elements from `expression` of type ARRAY, returning a single ARRAY as a result.

AVG().description: Returns the average of non-NULL input values, or NaN if the input contains a NaN.

BIT_AND().description: Performs a bitwise AND operation on `expression` and returns the result.

BIT_OR().description: Performs a bitwise OR operation on `expression` and returns the result.

BIT_XOR().description: Performs a bitwise XOR operation on `expression` and returns the result.

COUNT(*).description: Returns the number of rows in the input.

COUNT(expr).description: Returns the number of rows with `expression` evaluated to any value other than NULL.

COUNTIF().description: Returns the count of TRUE values for `expression`.

LOGICAL_AND().description: Returns the logical AND of all non-NULL expressions.

LOGICAL_OR().description: Returns the logical OR of all non-NULL expressions.

MAX().description: Returns the maximum value of non-NULL expressions.

MIN().description: Returns the minimum value of non-NULL expressions.

body: STRING_AGG(${1:[DISTINCT] expression [, delimiter] [ORDER BY key [{ASC|DESC\}] [, ... ]] [LIMIT n]})
description: Returns a value (either STRING or BYTES) obtained by concatenating non-null values.
Returns the sum of non-null values.
Returns the Pearson coefficient of correlation of a set of number pairs.
Returns the population covariance of a set of number pairs.
Returns the sample covariance of a set of number pairs.
Returns the population (biased) standard deviation of the values. The return result is between `0` and `+Inf`.
Returns the sample (unbiased) standard deviation of the values. The return result is between `0` and `+Inf`.
Returns the population (biased) variance of the values. The return result is between `0` and `+Inf`.
Returns the sample (unbiased) variance of the values. The return result is between `0` and `+Inf`.
Returns the approximate result for `COUNT(DISTINCT expression)`.

APPROX_QUANTILES().description: Returns the approximate boundaries for a group of `expression` values, where `number` represents the number of quantiles to create.

APPROX_TOP_COUNT().description: Returns the approximate top elements of `expression`.

description: Returns the approximate top elements of `expression`, based on the sum of an assigned `weight`. The `number` parameter specifies the number of elements returned.

HLL_COUNT.INIT().description: A scalar function that takes one or more input values and aggregates them into a HyperLogLog++ sketch.

description: An aggregate function that returns the cardinality of several HyperLogLog++ set sketches by computing their union.
An aggregate function that takes one or more HyperLogLog++ `sketch` inputs and merges them into a new sketch.
A scalar function that extracts an cardinality estimate of a single HyperLogLog++ sketch.

RANK().description: Returns the ordinal (1-based) rank of each row within the ordered partition.

DENSE_RANK().description: Returns the ordinal (1-based) rank of each row within the window partition.

PERCENT_RANK().description: Return the percentile rank of a row defined as (RK-1)/(NR-1), where RK is the `RANK` of the row and NR is the number of rows in the partition. Returns 0 if NR=1.

CUME_DIST().description: Return the relative rank of a row defined as NP/NR. NP is defined to be the number of rows that either precede or are peers with the current row. NR is the number of rows in the partition.

NTILE().description: This function divides the rows into `constant_integer_expression` buckets based on row ordering and returns the 1-based bucket number that is assigned to each row.

ROW_NUMBER().description: Does not require the `ORDER BY` clause.

description: Returns the value of the `value_expression` for the first row in the current window frame.
Returns the value of the `value_expression` for the last row in the current window frame.
Returns the value of `value_expression` at the Nth row of the current window frame, where Nth is defined by `constant_integer_expression`. Returns NULL if there is no such row.
Returns the value of the `value_expression` on a subsequent row.
Returns the value of the `value_expression` on a preceding row.
Computes the specified percentile value for the value_expression, with linear interpolation.
Computes the specified percentile value for a discrete `value_expression`.
The input, `expression`, must be an integer or BYTES.

SIGN().description: Returns -1, 0, or +1 for negative, zero and positive argument respectively.

IS_INF().description: Return TRUE if the value is positive or negative infinity.

IS_NAN().description: Return TRUE if the value is a `NaN` value.

description: Divides X by Y; never fails. Returns FLOAT64. Unlike division operator (/), does not generate errors for division by zero or overflow.

RAND().description: Generates a pseudo-random value of type FLOAT64 in the range of [0, 1), inclusive of 0 and exclusive of 1.

SQRT().description: Computes the square root of X.

POW().description: Power function: returns the value of X raised to the power of Y.

LN().description: Computes the natural logarithm of X.

LOG(X, Y).description: Computes logarithm of X to base Y.

LOG10().description: Similar to LOG(X) but computes logarithm to base 10.

GREATEST().description: Returns `NULL` if any of the inputs is `NULL`.

LEAST().description: Returns `NULL` if any of the inputs is `NULL`.

DIV().description: Returns the result of integer division of X by Y.

MOD().description: Modulo function: returns the remainder of the division of X by Y.

COS().description: Computes cosine of X. Never fails.

COSH().description: Computes the hyperbolic cosine of X.

ACOS().description: Computes the principal value of the arc cosine of X.

ACOSH().description: Computes the inverse hyperbolic cosine of X.

SIN().description: Computes the sine of X. Never fails.

SINH().description: Computes the hyperbolic sine of X.

ASIN().description: Computes the principal value of the arc sine of X.

ASINH().description: Computes the inverse hyperbolic sine of X. Does not fail.

TANH().description: Computes hyperbolic tangent of X. Does not fail.

ATAN().description: Computes the principal value of the arc tangent of X.

ATANH().description: Computes the inverse hyperbolic tangent of X.

ATAN2().description: Calculates the principal value of the arc tangent of Y/X using the signs of the two arguments to determine the quadrant.

FARM_FINGERPRINT().description: Computes the fingerprint of the STRING or BYTES input using the Fingerprint64 function from the open-source FarmHash library.

description: Computes the hash of the input using the MD5 algorithm.
Computes the hash of the input using the SHA-1 algorithm.
Computes the hash of the input using the SHA-256 algorithm.
Computes the hash of the input using the SHA-512 algorithm.

BYTE_LENGTH().description: Returns the length of the value in bytes, regardless of whether the type of the value is STRING or BYTES.

CHAR_LENGTH().description: Returns the length of the STRING in characters.

description: Takes an array of extended ASCII code points (ARRAY of INT64) and returns BYTES.
Takes an array of Unicode code points (ARRAY of INT64) and returns a STRING.

CONCAT().description: Concatenates one or more values into a single result.

ENDS_WITH().description: Takes two values. Returns TRUE if the second value is a suffix of the first.

FORMAT().description: BigQuery supports a FORMAT() function for formatting strings. This function is similar to the C printf function.

FROM_BASE32().description: Converts the base32-encoded input `string_expr` into BYTES format.

FROM_BASE64().description: Converts the base64-encoded input `string_expr` into BYTES format.

FROM_HEX().description: Converts a hexadecimal-encoded STRING into BYTES format.

LENGTH().description: Returns the length of the value.

description: Returns a value that consists of `original_value` prepended with `pattern`.
For STRING arguments, returns the original string with all alphabetic characters in lowercase.

LTRIM().description: Identical to TRIM, but only removes leading characters.

description: Takes a STRING, `value`, and returns it as a normalized string.

NORMALIZE_AND_CASEFOLD().description: Takes a STRING, `value`, and performs the same actions as NORMALIZE, as well as casefolding for case-insensitive operations.

description: Returns TRUE if `value` is a partial match for the regular expression, `regex`.
Returns the first substring in `value` that matches the regular expression, `regex`. Returns NULL if there is no match.
Returns an array of all substrings of `value` that match the regular expression, `regex`.
Returns a STRING where all substrings of `value` that match regular expression `regex` are replaced with `replacement`.

REPLACE().description: Replaces all occurrences of `from_value` with `to_value` in `original_value`.

description: Returns a value that consists of `original_value`, repeated.

REVERSE().description: Returns the reverse of the input STRING or BYTES.

description: Returns a value that consists of `original_value` appended with pattern.

RTRIM().description: Identical to TRIM, but only removes trailing characters.

SAFE_CONVERT_BYTES_TO_STRING().description: Converts a sequence of bytes to a string.

description: Splits `value` using the `delimiter` argument.

STARTS_WITH().description: Takes two values. Returns TRUE if the second value is a prefix of the first.

STRPOS().description: Returns the 1-based index of the first occurrence of `substring` inside `string`. Returns 0 if `substring` is not found.

description: Returns a substring of the supplied `value`.

TO_BASE32().description: Converts a sequence of BYTES into a base32-encoded STRING.

TO_BASE64().description: Converts a sequence of BYTES into a base64-encoded STRING.

description: Takes a value and returns an array of INT64.

TO_HEX().description: Converts a sequence of BYTES into a hexadecimal STRING.

TRIM().description: Removes all leading and trailing characters that match `value2`.

description: For STRING arguments, returns the original string with all alphabetic characters in uppercase.

JSON_EXTRACT().description: Which returns JSON values as STRINGs.

JSON_EXTRACT_SCALAR().description: Which returns scalar JSON values as STRINGs.

TO_JSON_STRING().description: Returns a JSON-formatted string representation of `value`.

ARRAY_CONCAT().description: Concatenates one or more arrays with the same element type into a single array.

ARRAY_LENGTH().description: Returns the size of the array.

description: Returns a concatenation of the elements in `array_expression` as a STRING. The value for `array_expression` can either be an array of STRING or BYTES data types.
Returns an array of values. The `start_expression` and `end_expression` parameters determine the inclusive start and end of the array.
Returns an array of dates. The `start_date` and `end_date` parameters determine the inclusive start and end of the array.
Returns an `ARRAY` of `TIMESTAMPS` separated by a given interval.

[OFFSET(zero_based_offset)].description: Accesses an ARRAY element by position and returns the element.

[ORDINAL(one_based_offset)].description: Accesses an ARRAY element by position and returns the element.

ARRAY_REVERSE().description: Returns the input ARRAY with elements in reverse order.

[SAFE_OFFSET(zero_based_offset)].description: Identical to `OFFSET` and `ORDINAL`, except returns `NULL` if the index is out of range.

[SAFE_ORDINAL(one_based_offset)].description: Identical to `OFFSET` and `ORDINAL`, except returns `NULL` if the index is out of range.

description: Returns the current date as of the specified or default timezone.
Returns the value corresponding to the specified date part. The `part` must be one of:

DATE(year, month, day).description: Constructs a `DATE` from `INT64` values representing the year, month, and day.

DATE(timestamp).description: Converts a `timestamp_expression` to a `DATE` data type.

description: Adds a specified time interval to a DATE.
Subtracts a specified time interval from a DATE.
Returns the number of `date_part` boundaries between the two `date_expression`s.
Truncates the date to the specified granularity.

DATE_FROM_UNIX_DATE().description: Interprets `INT64_expression` as the number of days since 1970-01-01.

description: Formats the `date_expr` according to the specified `format_string`.
Uses a `format_string` and a string representation of a date to return a DATE object.

UNIX_DATE().description: Returns the number of days since 1970-01-01.

description: Returns the current time as a DATETIME object.

DATETIME(year, month, day, hour, minute,.description: Constructs a `DATETIME` object using `INT64` values representing the year, month, day, hour, minute, and second.

DATETIME(date, time).description: Constructs a `DATETIME` object using a `DATE` object and a `TIME` object.

DATETIME(timestamp).description: Constructs a `DATETIME` object using a `TIMESTAMP` object.

description: Adds `INT64_expr` units of `part` to the DATETIME object.
Subtracts `INT64_expr` units of `part` from the DATETIME.
Returns the number of `part` boundaries between the two `datetime_expressions`.
Truncates a `DATETIME` object to the granularity of `part`.
Formats a DATETIME object according to the specified `format_string`.
Uses a `format_string` and a `string` representation of a timestamp to return a TIMESTAMP object.

CURRENT_TIME().description: Returns the current time as a TIME object.

TIME(hour, minute, second).description: Constructs a `TIME` object using `INT64` values representing the hour, minute, and second.

TIME(datetime).description: Constructs a `TIME` object using a `DATETIME` object.

TIME(timestamp).description: Constructs a `TIME` object using a `TIMESTAMP` object.

description: Adds `INT64_expr` units of `part` to the TIME object.
Subtracts `INT64_expr` units of `part` from the TIME object.
Returns the number of whole specified `part` intervals between two TIME objects.
Truncates a TIME object to the granularity of `part`.
Formats a TIME object according to the specified `format_string`.
Uses a `format_string` and a string to return a TIME object.
Returns an `INT64` value that corresponds to the specified `part` from a supplied `timestamp_expression`.
Converts a `timestamp_expression` to a STRING data type.

TIMESTAMP(string).description: Converts a STRING expression to a TIMESTAMP data type.

TIMESTAMP(date).description: Converts a DATE object to a TIMESTAMP data type.

TIMESTAMP(datetime).description: Converts a DATETIME object to a TIMESTAMP data type.

description: Adds `INT64_expr` units of `date_part` to the timestamp, independent of any time zone.
Subtracts `INT64_expr` units of `date_part` from the timestamp, independent of any time zone.
Returns the number of whole specified `date_part` intervals between two timestamps.
Truncates a timestamp to the granularity of `date_part`.
Formats a timestamp according to the specified `format_string`.
Uses a `format_string` and a string representation of a timestamp to return a TIMESTAMP object.

TIMESTAMP_SECONDS().description: Interprets `int64_expression` as the number of seconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC.

TIMESTAMP_MILLIS().description: Interprets `int64_expression` as the number of milliseconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC.

TIMESTAMP_MICROS().description: Interprets `int64_expression` as the number of microseconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC.

UNIX_SECONDS().description: Returns the number of seconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC.

UNIX_MILLIS().description: Returns the number of milliseconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC.

UNIX_MICROS().description: Returns the number of microseconds since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC.

SESSION_USER().description: Returns the email address of whoever is executing the query.

description: Converts an IPv4 or IPv6 address from text (STRING) format to binary (BYTES) format in network byte order.

NET.SAFE_IP_FROM_STRING().description: Similar to NET.IP_FROM_STRING, but returns `NULL` instead of throwing an error if the input is invalid.

description: Converts an IPv4 or IPv6 address from binary (BYTES) format in network byte order to text (STRING) format.

NET.IP_NET_MASK().description: Returns a network mask: a byte sequence with length equal to `num_output_bytes`, where the first `prefix_length` bits are set to 1 and the other bits are set to 0.

description: Takes `addr_bin`, an IPv4 or IPv6 address in binary (BYTES) format in network byte order, and returns a subnet address in the same format.
Converts an IPv4 address from integer format to binary (BYTES) format in network byte order.
Converts an IPv4 address from binary (BYTES) format in network byte order to integer format.

NET.HOST().description: Takes a URL as a STRING and returns the host as a STRING.

description: Takes a URL as a STRING and returns the public suffix (such as `com`, `org`, or `net`) as a STRING.
Takes a URL as a STRING and returns the registered or registerable domain (the public suffix plus one preceding label), as a STRING.

CASE expr WHEN value ... END.description: Compares `expr` to value of each successive `WHEN` clause and returns the first result where this comparison returns true.

COALESCE().description: Returns the value of the first non-null expression.

IF().description: If `cond` is true, returns `true_result`, else returns `else_result`.

NULLIF().description: Returns `NULL` if `expression = expression_to_match` is true, otherwise returns `expression`.

description: Returns an error. The error_message argument is a STRING.
If you begin a function with the SAFE. prefix, it will return NULL instead of an error.

INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SCHEMATA.description: When you query the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SCHEMATA view, the query results contain one row for each dataset in a project to which the current user has access.

INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SCHEMATA_OPTIONS.description: When you query the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SCHEMATA_OPTIONS view, the query results contain one row for each dataset in a project to which the current user has access.

INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES.description: When you query the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES view, the query results contain one row for each table or view in a dataset.

INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLE_OPTIONS.description: When you query the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLE_OPTIONS view, the query results contain one row for each table or view in a dataset.

INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS.description: When you query the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS view, the query results contain one row for each column (field) in a table.

INFORMATION_SCHEMA.VIEWS.description: When you query the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.VIEWS view, the query results contain one row for each view in a dataset.
